Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Student Travel Support for 16th International Conference on Verification, Model Checking and Abstract Interpretation (VMCAI)

This award will support student travel to the 2015 16th International Conference on Verification, Model Checking and Abstract Interpretation (VMCAI) . The conference will be held in Mumbai, India, in January 2015. VMCAI is a conference that bridges the gap between the various methodologies that are used for formal verification. The conference has brought together two communities---namely, the model checking community and the abstract interpretation-based program analysis community---both of which were largely independent 15 years ago. Supporting student travel to attend professional conferences and workshops is a very important mission of the NSF. Verification technology is being rapidly deployed in a variety of areas both in academic research as well as in industrial systems. Thus the broader significance and importance includes fostering the next generation of researchers in this research area, as well as providing international experiences to build a globally-aware workforce. In particular, students will have the opportunity to learn state-of-the-art methodologies, be exposed to novel techniques, and interact with senior researchers in their areas of expertise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Attending a conference can be a transformative experience for a young
researcher.  It exposes them to cutting-edge research and can help
them make connections to other students and senior researchers in the
area. Hence, encouraging attendance at conferences is critical for
promoting the development of students and post docs, especially those
that need to find jobs and enter the work force soon after the
conference.


This travel grant was originally intended to support the visit of 15
US-based students to attend the VMCAI 2015 conference, January 12-14,
2015 in Mumbai, India. The VMCAI conference is traditionally organized
as a co-located event of the POPL conference.  In 2015 the POPL
organizers managed to obtain many additional student support, so only
a small number of students applied for the VMCAI travel support. We
awarded two awards, but at the end, only one student attended the
conference. The other student could not attend due to the fact that he
did not receive the Indian visa in time. We applied for one year
extension to use the almost complete award for VMCAI 2016, which was
held Januray 17 - 19, 2016 in St. Petersburg, FL, USA. For VMCAI 2016
we awarded 6 student awards. After the VMCAI 2016 there was still
$12,500 money left from this grant.

In 2016 the PI Ruzica Piskac was the program chair / general chair for
the 16th conference on Formal Methods in Computer-Aided Design
(FMCAD), 3-6 October, 2016 in Mountain View, CA, USA. Continuing the
tradition of the previous years, FMCAD 2016 was hosting a Student
Forum that provided a platform for graduate students at any career
stage to introduce their research to the wider Formal Methods
community, and solicit feedback.  We asked NSF to grant us the
permission to use the remaining funds on this award to sponsor the
student travel's to the FMCAD conference. We only sponsored the
US-based students, and we sponsored the students who had their posters
accepted to the Student Forum.


In all three case, the grant covered travel costs, the conference fee,
meals and a shared accommodation. The awardees were reimbursed actual
travel costs, not giving them a lump sum. Some students asked for only
partial support since the parts of their travels were covered from
their universities.

After the conference we asked students to submit a small report on how
this grant help them. All their comments are given in the acompanying
report .PDF file. In general, we can see that all of the students said
that this grant was significantly beneficial for their development as
a researcher.

The students were chosen among the pool of applicants, with priority
being given to the under-representative groups. For all three
conferences this award was publicly advertised on the conference web
site. The acknowledgments to NSF were given. In addition, we put a
call for participation to various mailing lists. Moreover, to increase
visibility we contacted leading researchers in the field and informed
them about this travel award, asking them to advertise it further.
